counselling_module_sections.title: Elements of Communication
counselling_module_sections.introduction: The way we and our partners communicate and behave in our relationship can make or break the relationship. To make sure we’re stronger together, we should look at our communication.

accordion_content.title: Ways of communicating
accordion_content.description:
It’s about more than the words we use. It’s also about voice, tone, and body language. These are also known as the 3 “V”’s: Verbal, Vocal and Visual 

Verbal

  •  Words

Vocal

  •  Words

Visual 

  •  Gestures
  • Facial expressions
  • Eye contact / movements

counselling_module_sections.title: USING “I” STATEMENTS
counselling_module_sections.introduction: Now that we’ve talked about how positive or negative communication and behaviours like body language can influence the health of your relationship, let’s learn about and practice using what we call “assertive” communication. This is a way of communicating your needs in a healthy way. We’re going to practice using “I” statements, which is a way of saying how you feel so that you and your partner can open, rather than close, conversation on a difficult topic.

accordion_content.title: What is an “I” Statement
accordion_content.description:
• An “I” statement is a way of clearly expressing your point of view about a situation. It includes an expression of how a situation is affecting you and how you would like to see it change. 
  • The best “I” statement is free of specific demands and blame. It opens up the discussion and leaves the next move up to the other person. 
  • We should aim for “I” statements to be clear (that is, to the point) and clean (that is, free of blame and judgment). We should beware of “you” statements, which place blame on someone else, hold them responsible, demand change from them, or sound like a threat.

accordion_content.title: What’s a “you” Statement
accordion_content.description:
A “you” statement is not what we want because they are judgemental.

  • “You are such a disgrace to me. You are always getting drunk and flirting with other women. I don’t want to go to social events with you any more even if you are my husband. You must control yourself.” 
  • “You are always so drunk when you come home at night, and you never give me money to buy food. I don’t know why I ever moved in with you. You must stop going to that bar from now on!” 
  • Remember “you” statements close a discussion because they make the person you’re talking to feel defensive.

accordion_content.title: So Whats a good example of an “I” Statement
accordion_content.description:
More “I” Statement examples

  • “I felt very embarrassed last night because you were so drunk and you were letting that woman kiss you and dance with you in a very sexy way. If you are unhappy about our relationship and your mind is straying to thoughts of other women, I would like us to talk about it in private.” 
  • “When you come home at night after the bar, I feel disappointed, because I would like to see more of you, and I would like some money for food for the children. I would like us to discuss how we can make things better together.” 
  • These statements carry no blame and are phrased not to annoy the person we’re talking to. The expectations within them are presented in a nonjudgmental manner (there is no “you must...”) and are not accusing the listener. They state your expectations or hopes, but they do not demand that they be met.

counselling_module_sections.title: Consider how you talk to your partner or other loved ones:
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
How to do it:  It’s really great that you want to improve communication in your relationships. This is really important and can have a big impact on the health of your relationship overall. Effective communication can help build trust, intimacy, and openness. 

Think about what you learned from the video and the earlier content on the different V’s that contribute to our communication. Think about how each of these elements can be done in either a positive or a negative way.  

Reflect on the following questions:

  • What are positive things a partner can say? What are some negative things? By this we mean the words they use when you talk.
  • What about the voice your partner uses – how can it be positive or negative? By voice I mean pitch or volume of the way they speak to you.
  • What about body language? By body language I mean things like posture, facial expression, and proximity.
  • How do these things affect the way you react to what a partner is communicating to you?
  • Can you think of two ways your communication could improve in each of these areas?

counselling_module_sections.title: Key take out points
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
• This is a useful way of separating feelings and facts in order to clarify what the problem really is. 
  • The formula may seem strange and unfamiliar, but it can become more natural the more you use “I” statements. This is a tough discipline and needs practice! 
  • Remember it’s not guaranteed to work everytime. You can only control your own behavior in a conflict, not the other person’s, but hopefully with time you’ll both learn to respectfully handle conflict.
  • “I” statements can be used at work, at the market or the shops, with friends, on public transport, or at any time when you feel that your needs are
    not being met. They are not just for use with a partner, so you can start practicing with others if practicing with your partner is too hard!

accordion_content.title: Using “I” Statements
accordion_content.description:
Consider what you’ve already learned about good communication, including your voice, tone, and body language. Now let’s use those while we also adjust our words through “I” statements.. 

How to do it:  It’s really great that you want to improve communication in your relationships. We all have conflicts with our partners and other people in our lives. It’s important to address these conflicts so that we can improve our relationships and I-statements can help.

accordion_content.title: Reflect on the following questions
accordion_content.description:
• Let’s think about some things that are particularly challenging between you and your partner, or someone else, and try to come up with an “I” statement about them. First, think about two topics you fight about most often? 
  • Now, think about the most recent time you fought about one of those topics. Can you come up with one “I” statement that you could have used? 
  • What do you think about this approach? What would be useful or not useful? 
  • Can you commit to using at least one “I” statement with your partner, or someone else in your life, the next time you have a disagreement?

counselling_module_sections.title: Decreasing Conflict
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
Let’s talk a little more about conflict in relationships. Conflict is part of every relationship, but it is important to learn how to deal with conflict in a healthy way to have a healthy relationship. Conflicts get worse when we ignore them or when one or both people start using “dirty fighting” and emotionally abusive and controlling behaviors. 

Let’s learn some more about “dirty fighting.” When we use “dirty fighting” we move from the issue level (where we respectfully talk about the issue at hand and seek compromise, etc.), to the personality level (e.g., making statements such as, “You’re a drunk”). From the personality level, couples often move to the relationship level, where they question the relationship (e.g., making statements such as, “If you don’t like it, leave me!”).

accordion_content.title: Clean up your fighting
accordion_content.description:
How to do it:

  • Review the types of dirty conflict and tips for decreasing conflict
  • Think about an argument you have with your partner. Consider if you used any types of dirty fighting. What were they? What was their impact? How did they make the conversation harder?
  • What’s an alternative approach you could use in the future?
  • The next time you find yourself in a conflict with your partner, make an active effort to avoid the “dirty fighting” and engage in more constructive behaviors instead. Don’t be too hard on yourself if you slip up—it can be challenging to stay focused during the heat of an argument, and these habits can take time to change.
  • After the conflict, make a note of how things went. Did you or your partner engage in any of the “dirty fighting” behaviors, and if so, did you catch yourself and try to take a different approach during the conflict? What went well, and what could you improve for next time?
  • If you feel comfortable, you can share the information about dirty fighting and decreasing conflict with your partner so they can also help improve how you handle conflict.

 

Why do it:

Most couples have conflict in their relationship from time to time, and while that’s not a bad thing, it can sometimes elicit destructive behaviors that contribute to you feeling bad in your relationship. If you can identify the destructive behaviors you can reduce them and replace them with more helpful behaviors, which can in turn improve communication and increase satisfaction. This process takes time and practice, and in some cases couples may benefit from seeking the support of a relationship counselor. See our list of resources for places where you can get that extra help.

accordion_content.title: The five types of dirty fighting
accordion_content.description:
1. Criticism (What is it: when you point out your partner’s weaknesses. This is often done in absolute terms, which means you use words like ‘never’ or ‘always’, for example, “you never think about me”; What’s an alternative: it’s okay to share with your partner what you don’t like about their behavior, but try to focus on your feelings using “I” statements rather than defining them by their behavior, which suggests they can’t change.) 
  2. Defensiveness (What is it: tendency to react, quick to take offense. This often happens when you feel attacked or criticized. It also involves pushing the blame onto the other person so that you don’t take responsibility. The problem with this is it shows that you’re not listening to your partner’s complaint or taking them seriously. It can also make your partner feel defensive. What’s an alternative: Try to listen to your partner’s complaint and take it seriously. Take responsibility and apologize when it’s appropriate.) 
  3. Belittling (What is it: making your partner feel “small,” name calling. this and the next form of “dirty fighting” can start to build up to make you feel bad about the relationship and your partner feel bad about themselves. What’s an alternative: Take a break from the conflict and think about the positive qualities your partner has so that you can return to the conflict and not insult your partner.) 
  4. Humiliation (What is it: embarrassing your partner, often in front of others.) 
  5. Withdrawing (What is it: refusing to talk, silent treatment. This can also take the form of leaving in the middle of an argument. Remember it’s okay to take a break from an argument if tension is high, but it’s good to communicate about the break. This type of behavior can make your partner feel rejected or abandoned. What’s an alternative: If you need time out to take a few deep breaths and collect your thoughts, let your partner know, and then return to the conversation when you’re ready. This way, your partner will understand that you are taking care of yourself, not trying to reject them.)

Happy couples still have disagreements, but they don’t use dirty fighting, or they apologize quickly when they do. When a simple argument looks like it’s getting out of hand, they’ll say things like:  “I can see you’re upset and want to talk, but I’m feeling overwhelmed and I would hear you better if we wait to talk about this until tomorrow.” 

Let’s think about the conflicts you say you usually have with your partner. When you fight, do you usually fight about an issue, your partner’s characteristics, or about the relationship?

counselling_module_action_points.title: Think of two ways to improve the words, tone of voice, and body language I use when talking to my partner
Use an ‘I’ statement with my partner or someone else
Identify types of ‘dirty fighting’ I use
Commit to staying focused on the issue in my next conflict
Commit to avoiding ‘dirty fighting’ in my next conflict
Talk to my partner about what I learned and ways to improve our communication
Share materials from this site with my partner
